author: John Woodrow Cox
title: Will Democratic candidates offer true progress?
text:
Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.) speaks in Tucson. (Rick Scuteri/Associated Press) By Editorial Board October 12 at 7:33 PM AS THE Democratic Party’s presidential candidates prepared for their first debate Tuesday night, the big story in the campaign was the rise of left-wing populism. Even before Hillary Clinton’s e-mail travails, socialist Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.) was making surprising headway against the front-running former secretary of state by promising a “ political revolution ” against the “billionaire class,” featuring such crowd-pleasing ideas as a higher top income tax rate, a breakup of “too big to fail” banks, opposition to the Trans-Pacific Partnership, a hike in the minimum wage, free college tuition and so on. The net effect has been to push the party’s reigning ideology leftward, since the other candidates’ responses to Mr. Sanders have often been some version of “me too.”
Ours is more in the vein of “not so fast.” Whether denouncing the influence of big money in politics or decrying the top-heavy distribution of income, Mr. Sanders identifies real issues.
